articles.title: Tired all the time? There may be a simple reason for that
articles.trailText: Levels of fatigue among women in Britain are soaring, and this isn’t the kind that can be cured by a nap. What lies behind the exhaustion epidemic?
articles.summary: Britain’s widespread fatigue among women often stems from unrecognised iron deficiency: one-third of women 19–49 have low ferritin, yet GPs frequently miss diagnosis by checking only haemoglobin. Symptoms—severe exhaustion, brain fog, hair loss, heavy periods—are dismissed as lifestyle or mental-health issues. Oral iron supplements help only some; many need costly IV infusions (£600/NHS) but face long waits. Experts cite medical misogyny, dietary shifts (non-heme vs heme iron), and lack of routine screening. Advocates urge ferritin tests for symptomatic women and streamlined infusion pathways to restore women’s health and productivity.

articles.title: How scientists are shining light on the biology behind seasonal affective disorder
articles.trailText: Researchers tracking large cohorts are discovering the effects of sleep, light and therapy on people impacted by winter’s arrival
articles.summary: Researchers have shown that seasonal affective disorder (SAD)—a winter-onset subtype of depression marked by low energy, hypersomnia and carb cravings—stems from endogenous shifts in circadian biology triggered by reduced daylight. Large-scale cohorts like the UK Biobank reveal seasonal gene expression changes and sleep pattern drift. Bright light therapy (10,000 lux for 20–30 minutes at dawn) and early outdoor exposure help reset the circadian clock by suppressing excess melatonin, while CBT for SAD reframes winter expectations. Simple measures—consistent sleep–wake times, morning sun, outdoor activity and cosy rituals—can mitigate the winter blues, but persistent symptoms warrant professional help.

articles.title: Everyone says they are worried about hate crimes. But Australia’s laws to combat them are all over the place
articles.trailText: Some state police forces have specific laws and units relating to hate crime, others have neither. Experts say a national definition is needed
articles.summary: Australia’s hate-crime laws vary by state: while NSW and WA now have dedicated units, Northern Territory, South Australia and Tasmania rely on prejudice as sentencing aggravators. Since 2020 researchers identified 435 charges nationwide (unknown convictions); Queensland led with 125 vilification charges. Federal AFP’s Operation Avalite has yielded seven antisemitism prosecutions. A Senate inquiry has urged a nationally consistent definition and database, but data gaps and misclassification persist. Experts say uniform legislation and improved tracking are essential to gauge rising antisemitism and Islamophobia amid global conflicts.

articles.title: Ministers were warned of errors at jail that released sex offender by mistake
articles.trailText: Chaotic release procedures at HMP Chelmsford were flagged to the prisons minister last year
articles.summary: An independent monitoring board report warned last year that chaotic release procedures at HMP Chelmsford risked prisoners “falling through the cracks” after a mix-up of release dates and missed briefings led to the accidental freedom of convicted child sex offender Hadush Kebatu. Kebatu, an Ethiopian asylum seeker convicted of sexual assaults on a 14-year-old and a woman, was re-arrested days later in London and deported. Prisons minister James Timpson acknowledged local concerns but did not address procedure failings. Justice secretary David Lammy has since launched an inquiry chaired by Lynne Owens and pledged the strongest release checks ever.

articles.title: ‘Out of reach’: stalled newbuilds leave Labour’s social housing targets in tatters
articles.trailText: As some families face a 200-year wait for an affordable home, what exactly has gone wrong?
articles.summary: England builds just over 10,000 social homes a year—far below the 90,000 needed and Labour’s pledge of 1.5 million new homes in five years—leaving some families facing 200-year waits. London developments have stalled, prompting a cut in affordable quotas from 35% to 20% for fast-track sites. High interest rates, surging material costs, Brexit-linked labour shortages and retrofit bills squeeze housing associations. Planning delays and missing landlord contracts stall 10,000 homes, while community resistance to densification further impedes progress. Despite a £39 billion investment and planning reforms, delivery remains painfully slow and targets out of reach.

articles.title: Woman turned away from UK-Italy flight due to ill child has benefit stopped
articles.trailText: Family denied entry at gate after one of their children had epileptic seizure – but HMRC said she took a one-way trip
articles.summary: Sally and her family were denied boarding on a July holiday flight to Italy after her child suffered an epileptic seizure. Sixteen months later HMRC halted her child benefit for three children, misinterpreting a one-way flight booking as emigration. She submitted airline letters and insurance claims to prove they never left the UK. This error is one of 23,500 similar cases triggered by a government crackdown using border and booking data. HMRC has apologised, pledging not to suspend payments before contacting recipients. Critics warn data inaccuracies and process flaws risk penalising law-abiding families and question Home Office data sources.

articles.title: Charities and stars call on UK government to set child poverty reduction targets
articles.trailText: Signatories of open letter include National Children’s Bureau, Barnardo’s and celebrities such as Emilia Clarke
articles.summary: An open letter coordinated by Big Issue founder Lord John Bird and signed by Emilia Clarke, Chris Packham, George Clarke, over 20 MPs and peers (Labour, Greens, SNP) and leading charities (National Children’s Bureau, Child Poverty Action Group, Barnardo’s, Amnesty UK, Trussell) urges the UK government to set binding child poverty reduction targets. Critics warn warm words won’t deliver change amid delays to Labour’s child poverty strategy and growing hardship—100,000 more children fall into poverty annually, nearly 5 million projected by 2029. Bird’s amendment to legally mandate targets was rejected in June but will be reintroduced in the Lords. The strategy, now slated for the November budget alongside a two-child benefit overhaul, risks half-measures, charity and think-tank analysis warns. The government pledges a £500 m investment in Best Start hubs, extended free meals and a £1 bn holiday crisis fund but has yet to set quantifiable benchmarks.

articles.title: Drone-blocking technology ‘urgently’ required at jails in England and Wales
articles.trailText: Ability to maintain control in prisons ‘critically undermined’ by scale of illicit drug trade, MPs say
articles.summary: The Commons justice select committee warns organised gangs exploit sophisticated drones—sightings up 770% since 2019—to smuggle drugs into prisons, with 39% of inmates reporting easy access and 11–19% developing new addictions. It demands urgent rollout of SkyFence or equivalent drone-jamming systems in all category A facilities within two years and estate-wide within 24 months, deeming current police and NCA measures inadequate. Government figures show 38,042 inmates freed early under an overcrowding scheme since September 2024.

articles.title: Nearly 150,000 aged 90 and above wait 12 hours in England’s A&Es each year
articles.trailText: Older people left in their own excrement and wet beds for hours and forced to watch others die, Age UK report finds
articles.summary: An Age UK report reveals that 149,293 people aged 90+ in England waited over 12 hours in A&E departments in 2024-25—one-third of attendances—amid more than one million 60+ patients facing similar delays. Many spent days in corridors, left in soiled beds, denied pain relief and forced to witness deaths. Caroline Abrahams called it “a crisis hiding in plain sight,” urging a government plan with clear targets and funding to end corridor care. MPs, nursing bodies and NHS leaders demand urgent action; ministers pledge £450 m for new urgent care centres.

articles.title: Jaywick’s continued decline and intensifying London poverty tell same story of ‘broken’ Britain
articles.trailText: Latest deprivation index shows how geography and housing costs shape inequality more than policy ever has
articles.summary: Jaywick Sands has topped England’s deprivation index since 2010, becoming a symbol of economic neglect, austerity and geographic isolation, scoring in the worst 10% for employment, income, health, crime, housing access and environment. While local MP Nigel Farage offered vague condolences, council leader Mark Stephenson cited recent progress and strong community spirit. Other post-industrial hubs like Blackpool and Birmingham remain chronically deprived, highlighting a static hierarchy unaffected by “levelling up.” Newly adjusted measures that factor in housing costs reveal extreme child poverty in 31 inner London pockets—Tower Hamlets 71%, Hackney 64%, Newham 60%, Islington 53%—reshaping funding allocations and sparking north–south resource tensions.

articles.title: Living with the hidden horrors of illegal HMOs  | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Aditya Chakrabortty on the scandal involving houses in multiple occupation
articles.summary: A resident describes two unlicensed HMOs in their six-flat block being illegally overcrowded with up to eight adults despite permission for three, resulting in broken furniture, urine-soaked mattresses and cockroach infestations. The housing association has dismissed repeated tenant complaints as “unproven” to protect landlords’ rights. Correspondents urge strict enforcement: confiscate and renovate non-compliant properties, fund courts for swift action, and allow tenants to reclaim rent for unlicensed HMOs. They fault underfunded councils, overwhelmed courts and buy-to-let incentives for enabling exploitative conditions and call for stronger regulation and accountability.

articles.title: Why can’t we eradicate both pensioner and child poverty? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Carole Easton and Dr Steve Cushion say that we should not pit one disadvanted group against another when it comes to the government’s funding priorities
articles.summary: Dr Carole Easton and Dr Steve Cushion argue that framing pensioner versus child poverty as a trade-off is misguided: over 2m pensioners live in poverty and hasty triple lock cuts risk deepening their hardship. The state pension reflects intergenerational solidarity, with today’s workers funding retired generations. They warn against ageist rhetoric and stress that without carefully planned reforms and a shift in national priorities, impoverished children will become impoverished pensioners. They note no guarantee savings from scaling back the triple lock would aid children and caution that sudden reforms could skyrocket pensioner poverty.

articles.title: Alan Kilburn obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Housing association chief executive who pioneered the use of private finance to support social housing
articles.summary: Alan Kilburn, OBE, died at 89; as chief executive of North Housing in the 1980s, he led major regeneration of Georgian and Victorian terraces in Newcastle, insisted tenants own their homes, served as 1982-83 president of the Chartered Institute of Housing and on the Duke of Edinburgh’s Inquiry, forging £65m in private finance amid cutbacks. He rebranded North as Home in 1995, expanded across England, and later held non-executive directorships at Barratt, Northern Rock Foundation, Affinity Sutton and Centre for Life. A founder of disability charity Azure, he began as a housing manager in Peterlee and is survived by his wife Doreen and two children.

articles.title: Almost all children in 73 areas of England live in low-income households
articles.trailText: New official measures show levelling up attempts have failed to shift high levels of deprivation
articles.summary: Revised 2025 indices of multiple deprivation show 73 English neighbourhoods where ≥99% of children live in income-deprived families once high rents are factored in, including 31 micro-areas in inner London (Tower Hamlets, Hackney, Haringey, Westminster). Blackpool, Middlesbrough, Burnley, Manchester and Birmingham remain the five most deprived local authorities; Jaywick in Essex again ranks worst at neighbourhood level. The housing-cost adjustment reframes child poverty as a capital crisis, may alter November’s council funding formula and impact local authority and NHS budgets amid the government’s pending child-poverty strategy. Coastal towns still feature heavily, though some areas have seen relief through gentrification.

articles.title: UK woman who booked Oslo flight but did not fly loses child benefit ‘because she emigrated’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: HMRC told Lisa Morris-Almond there was no record of her return to UK, but she did not take the trip
articles.summary: Lisa Morris-Almond had her UK child benefit frozen after HMRC wrongly flagged her as emigrated based on a booked but never flown London–Oslo flight. She joins 23,500 parents suspended in a pilot fraud crackdown driven by Border Force passenger data rather than PAYE tax records. HMRC apologised, halted pre-emptive suspensions, reinstated PAYE cross-checks and urged affected claimants to answer a simplified questionnaire. The scheme, which had reviewed 1.5 million of 6.9 million beneficiaries and restored 589 payments so far, faces Lib Dem demands for parliamentary scrutiny amid reports of similar false positives, such as a woman flagged post-Eurostar trip.

articles.title: Only full abolition of two-child benefit cap will substantially cut poverty, thinktank says
articles.trailText: Resolution Foundation says half-measures would have little or no meaningful impact on child poverty rates
articles.summary: Resolution Foundation warns only fully scrapping the two-child benefit cap will meaningfully reduce child poverty, cutting 330,000 children out of poverty today and 150,000 by 2029-30; partial measures (lifting the limit for working families, raising it to three/four children or tapered payments) would barely alter rates. Introduced in 2017, the cap blocks £3,500 per additional child, affecting 1.7 million youngsters, and, unless abolished, is set to drive poverty from 31% to 34% by 2029-30. Existing boosts to universal credit, free school meals and crisis funds are insufficient, the thinktank concludes.

articles.title: Patients go to court to stop embryos being destroyed after admin error
articles.trailText: Lawyer says ‘difficult to understand’ rules on storage consent led to confusion and left clients ‘in limbo’
articles.summary: A group of at least 15 fertility patients, including cancer survivors, are suing to prevent their frozen embryos being destroyed after clinics missed consent renewals due to errors in applying 2022 and 2020 storage extensions (from 10 to 55 years with 10-year consent cycles). Clinics failed to notify or held wrong expiry data while still accepting payments. Lawyers argue this breaches Article 8 rights and seek a court order to allow six-month windows to renew consent. The HFEA and DH support case-by-case relief; judgment pending from Mrs Justice Morgan.

articles.title: Robert Wilkinson obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Local authority community worker who became a freelance expert in recording oral history
articles.summary: Robert Wilkinson, who died aged 73 of Lewy body dementia, spent over 30 years as a Waltham Forest community worker (1977–1998), later managing lottery funding bids in Camden and securing more than £15 million for local projects. In 1983 he co-founded the Waltham Forest Oral History Workshop, served as treasurer of the Oral History Society and worked freelance from 2007 to 2020, including residencies at Kettle’s Yard and the British Library. A lifelong socialist, union rep and school governor, he is survived by his wife Val, three sons and five grandchildren.

articles.title: Councils in England face clampdown on four-day working weeks
articles.trailText: Steve Reed writes to South Cambridgeshire council raising concerns over performance and value for money
articles.summary: Local government secretary Steve Reed has written to South Cambridgeshire council—the only English authority formally trialing a four-day, 32-hour week at full pay—warning it has damaged housing services, citing declines in rent collection, reletting times and tenant satisfaction. Reed has sought formal assurances and a meeting to mitigate further service impacts amid broader government guidance discouraging shortened workweeks. Council leader Bridget Smith disputes these findings, highlighting £400K savings, 41% lower turnover, improved recruitment and stable performance across most KPIs. Ministers can only discourage, not ban, such trials. The 4 Day Week Foundation’s Joe Ryle decries the clampdown.

articles.title: HMRC pauses child benefit crackdown after 23,500 families caught up in data error
articles.trailText: Parents say they were treated as fraudsters because Home Office travel records failed to show their return to UK
articles.summary: HMRC has paused suspending child benefit payments after flawed Home Office travel data wrongly halted 23,500 cases, misidentifying routine holidays, work trips and Belfast–Dublin returns as fraud. A Guardian/Detail probe revealed parents flagged despite legitimate travel—eg, a working trip to Amsterdam before birth, a repatriation from France—and forced to supply years of bank statements. Following two apologies, HMRC will cross-check PAYE records, verify eligibility before action and deploy a dedicated team to reinstate benefits without lengthy interviews. MP Paul Kohler has urged strong safeguards for Northern Ireland families; an urgent review is underway.

articles.title: Hundreds of hospice beds and staff cut in England  amid funding crisis
articles.trailText: National Audit Office reports nearly two-thirds of independent hospices in deficit in 2023-24 as demand increases
articles.summary: A National Audit Office report finds that in 2023–24 nearly two-thirds of England’s independent hospices ran a £78 m deficit, forcing cuts to about 300 inpatient beds and staff despite rising palliative-care demand. Only 29% of hospice income came from government, the rest from charities, creating a postcode lottery in service provision. With ministers unaware of their reliance on the sector, the NAO urges the Department of Health and NHS England to assess funding resilience and plan for future end-of-life care needs.

articles.title: ‘No more children are going to die like you’: how Sheffield mother kept her promise to boys killed by father 11 years ago
articles.trailText: Claire Throssell has been central to the campaign to repeal parental contact laws following the deaths of her two sons at the hands of their father in 2014
articles.summary: Claire Throssell, whose sons Jack (12) and Paul (9) were killed by their father during an unsupervised, court-ordered visit in 2014, has spearheaded the Child First campaign with Women’s Aid to repeal the legal presumption of parental contact after her warnings of violence were ignored. Eleven years after promising Jack “no more children will die like you,” she met the prime minister as the government announced plans to scrap that presumption. A new report logged 67 similar deaths over 30 years, and Throssell continues to push for child-safety reforms.

articles.title: NHS makes morning-after pill available for free across pharmacies in England
articles.trailText: Those in need of free emergency contraception no longer have to see their GP or attend a sexual health clinic
articles.summary: The NHS has expanded free access to the morning-after pill across nearly 10,000 pharmacies in England, removing the need for GP or clinic appointments and ending a postcode lottery where costs reached up to £30. National clinical director Dr Sue Mann calls it the biggest change to sexual health services since the 1960s and a key step in shifting care into communities, with four in five people living within a 20-minute walk of a pharmacy. The rollout coincides with new pharmacy support for patients newly prescribed antidepressants. Industry and government leaders stress the need for sustainable funding to keep pharmacies at the heart of accessible reproductive and mental healthcare.

articles.title: Five more prisoners freed in error after sex offender’s release from Essex jail
articles.trailText: Union says staff shortages and confusion over early release schemes are driving a rise in mistakes
articles.summary: The Prison Officers’ Association says five additional inmates were mistakenly released in one week across five facilities—including HMP Pentonville, Durham, The Mount and Reading Crown Court—after a convicted sex offender’s accidental early release from HMP Chelmsford sparked public outrage. One released prisoner remains at large. The union blames staffing shortages, inadequate training and confusing early-release schemes introduced to ease overcrowding. Justice Secretary David Lammy described the blunder as human error and has ordered immediate tightening of release checks. MoJ data show error releases rose 128% to 262 in the year to March 2025.

articles.title: EHRC guidance will help businesses comply with the law on sex and gender | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Kishwer Falkner , chair of the Equality and Human Rights Commission, says its updated code of practice will balance the rights of service users and protect all from discrimination
articles.summary: Kishwer Falkner, EHRC chair, reassures businesses that the EHRC’s updated code of practice on sex and gender under the Equality Act—submitted to government seven weeks ago—will clarify legal duties after the Supreme Court’s redefinition of “sex.” Informed by consultations with over 50,000 organisations and individuals, it offers practical examples to help service providers balance user rights and avoid discrimination. While not exhaustive, it may necessitate policy changes or facility reconfigurations. Falkner emphasises that compliance with the Equality Act is mandatory, as litigation risks outweigh implementation costs, and that the EHRC advises on but does not create the law.

articles.title: Gambling does not cause any ‘social ills’, lobbyist tells incredulous MPs
articles.trailText: Head of UK’s Betting and Gaming Council was asked to repeat claim as she spoke against increasing taxes on sector in November budget
articles.summary: Grainne Hurst, chief executive of the Betting and Gaming Council, told MPs on the Treasury select committee that gambling causes no “social ills” and warned that higher taxes in the November budget would jeopardize jobs, high-street betting shops and sports sponsorship. Under scrutiny from chair Meg Hillier and member John Glen, she insisted the sector is properly taxed and further levies would push punters into unregulated markets. Expert witnesses—including ex-Paddy Power director Stewart Kenny and policy analysts—urged higher taxes on risky products like online casinos while keeping lower rates on horse-racing and bingo. MPs now await Chancellor Rachel Reeves’s budget decision amid industry threats of shop closures.

articles.title: Bankrupt Woking to get £500m bailout in Surrey council shake-up
articles.trailText: ‘Unprecedented’ move helps to smooth over creation of two new ‘mega council’ unitary authorities
articles.summary: Ministers will underwrite a £500m bailout for bankrupt Woking borough, wiping out part of its £2bn debt racked up by risky Tory-era investments. The unprecedented intervention by communities secretary Steve Reed paves the way for Labour’s plan to merge Surrey’s county and 11 district/borough councils into two unitary “mega” authorities. West Surrey will combine Woking with five boroughs, East Surrey merges six districts, aiming to deliver efficiency savings, devolution and service improvements. Additional support may follow if asset disposals and grants fall short. The shake-up marks England’s largest local government reorganisation since the 1970s.

articles.title: Exclamation marks! Why do women use them three times as much as men?
articles.trailText: It’s the punctuation that can make you seem warmer and more agreeable – but also much more compliant and lacking in analytical thinking
articles.summary: New Journal of Experimental Social Psychology research finds women use exclamation marks three times more often than men, driven by a need to appear warm and approachable in text-based communication where neutral punctuation can seem cold or hostile. While exclamation marks boost perceived friendliness, overuse undermines authority and analytical credibility, explaining their absence in formal proclamations like royal announcements. Inflation of exclamation marks in casual writing—exacerbated by Gen Z’s aversion to periods—diminishes their impact, fueling a cycle of increasing punctuation intensity to signal warmth.

articles.title: Black women with fibroids face delays and poor care in the UK, says report
articles.trailText: Exclusive: All-party parliamentary group on black health found 27% not offered any treatment after diagnosis
articles.summary: All-party parliamentary group on Black health’s report, based on a survey of over 500 women (70% Black British), reveals UK Black women with uterine fibroids face systemic neglect: 27% were offered no treatment post-diagnosis, over half waited at least two years for a diagnosis, and a quarter endured fibroids for more than a decade. Disproportionate first-line hysterectomies overshadow under-utilised non-surgical options. Only six UK studies on fibroids ran between 2014–21. Experts and MPs call for urgent research, policy reform, improved screening, and equitable care to address this reproductive health emergency.

articles.title: HMRC cuts child benefit for 23,500 families based on incomplete travel data
articles.trailText: UK tax agency apologises after flagging people as having emigrated, often when they return via different routes
articles.summary: HMRC suspended child benefit for 23,489 of 6.9m claimants after its crackdown flagged one‐way travel data as evidence of emigration. Affected families – from parents doing one‐day autism‐support trips to Amsterdam to bereaved relatives flying via Dublin – were wrongly classed as living abroad, faced suspension demands and had to produce bank, school and GP records. HMRC apologised, is reviewing systems and says most cases were valid suspensions; ministers claim the fraud drive could save £350m with expanded investigator teams.

articles.title: Picture of health: going to art galleries can improve wellbeing, study reveals
articles.trailText: Viewing original works of art can relieve stress, cut heart disease risk and boost immune system, first study of its kind finds
articles.summary: A UK study led by King’s College London measured physiological responses of 50 adults (aged 18–40) viewing original Manet, Van Gogh and Gauguin art at the Courtauld Gallery versus reproductions outside a gallery. Gallery viewers saw cortisol levels drop by 22% (vs 8%), IL-6 and TNF-alpha fall by 30% and 28%, plus increased heart rate and skin-temperature dips. Findings show original art simultaneously modulates immune, endocrine and autonomic systems to reduce stress and boost wellbeing. Art Fund calls benefits universal, urging gallery visits.

articles.title: Cyclist gets 3D-printed face after drunk driver left him with third-degree burns
articles.trailText: Dave Richards, 75, who suffered full-thickness burns, given mimetic prosthetic by new NHS 3D medical centre
articles.summary: Dave Richards, 75, was left with full-thickness third-degree burns to one side of his face, back, pelvis and multiple ribs after a speeding drunk driver hit him in July 2021 while he cycled. Surgeons removed his eye to avoid infection, reconstructed his face with a free flap from his neck, and have now fitted him with a custom 3D-printed prosthetic face—matching his skin, hair and eye colour—produced at Bristol’s new NHS 3D medical centre integrating scanning, design and printing. The driver received a three-year sentence, served one and a half years on good behaviour.

articles.title: Foster carers across England facing widespread racism, sector leader says
articles.trailText: Government urged to act over ‘impact of far-right sentiment’ on children, foster carers and social workers
articles.summary: Harvey Gallagher, chief executive of the Nationwide Association of Fostering Providers, warns of widespread racism, extremism and far-right sentiment undermining foster care in England. He cites reports of BAME foster children too fearful to leave home, white carers questioned in public over ethnically diverse placements, and African-Caribbean and Asian social workers facing their “most racist” working environments. Gallagher has urged children’s minister Josh MacAlister for urgent government guidance to tackle normalized discriminatory attitudes, protect unaccompanied asylum-seekers and prevent a hostile climate that could drive vulnerable youth toward radicalisation. A coalition of 150+ charities backs the call. The education department pledges new recruitment hubs, £500m early intervention funding and forthcoming reforms.

articles.title: Ministers warned not to scapegoat prison staff over mistaken release of Hadush Kebatu
articles.trailText: Justice secretary blames human error but other say there are systemic problems and targeting an individual is ‘unjust’
articles.summary: Justice Secretary David Lammy has ordered an inquiry, chaired by Lynne Owens, after asylum seeker Hadush Kebatu—convicted of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old—was mistakenly freed from HMP Chelmsford and re-arrested two days later. The Prison Officers’ Association condemns the suspension of a single discharge manager while senior staff share blame, and chief inspector Charlie Taylor warns that release errors are “endemic” across an overstretched system. Ministers will impose a five-page checklist and stricter ID checks, yet governors say these measures won’t fix deep staffing cuts and systemic breakdowns.

articles.title: ‘Gross failure’ led to deaths of mother and baby in Prestwich home birth
articles.trailText: Jennifer Cahill and her daughter, Agnes Lily, died in birth described by coroner as ‘a Victorian-age nightmare’
articles.summary: An inquest into the June 2024 home birth of Jennifer Cahill in Prestwich concluded that a 'gross failure' by community midwives and NHS trust advice led to her fatal postpartum haemorrhage and newborn Agnes Lily’s death days later. Despite Cahill’s high-risk status after a previous severe hemorrhage, she received inadequate risk assessment, unclear guidance on hospital delivery, poor communication of her birth plan and exhausted midwives failed to monitor vital signs properly. Coroner Joanne Kearsley condemned the 'Victorian-age nightmare' and will recommend urgent training and referral process reforms.

articles.title: Men need twice as much exercise as women to lower heart disease risk, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers suggest ‘sex-specific strategies’ after analysis of cardiovascular health improvements
articles.summary: Analysis of UK Biobank data from 80,243 adults finds women achieve a 30% drop in coronary heart disease risk with 250 minutes of weekly exercise, while men require 530 minutes to match this benefit. Women meeting standard 150-minute guidelines saw a 22% risk reduction over eight years; men saw 17%. Among 5,000+ patients with existing heart disease, active women had a threefold lower mortality risk compared to active men. Published in Nature Cardiovascular Research by Dr. Jiajin Chen et al at Xiamen University, the study suggests tailoring guidelines to account for sex differences.

articles.title: NHS trust pleads guilty after teenage girl absconded from 24-hour care and killed herself
articles.trailText: Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, suffered with severe mental health problems and absconded from Worthing hospital in March 2022
articles.summary: University Hospitals Sussex NHS Trust pleaded guilty at Brighton magistrates to failing to provide safe care after 16-year-old Ellame Ford-Dunn, diagnosed with autism, ADHD and dyslexia, absconded from its Bluefin acute children’s ward in March 2022 and killed herself minutes later. The court heard the trust’s 2019 missing-patient policy lacked guidance on pursuing vulnerable absconders. Admitted amid a national shortage of child mental-health beds, the ward lacked resources. UHSussex faces sentencing on 26 November and further manslaughter probes.

articles.title: Physiotherapy care in decline because of poor NHS facilities, poll shows
articles.trailText: Six in 10 practitioners say loss of rehabilitation space in hospitals is harming chances of patients recovering
articles.summary: Survey of 2,000 NHS physiotherapists by the Chartered Society of Physiotherapists finds 40% have lost dedicated rehab space, 60% had rooms reallocated, and 74% report a decline in rehab quality. Fifty-seven percent lack essential equipment, driving 51% to see increased patient disability and 53% more readmissions. Stroke rehab gyms cut to 15 m² struggle to meet three hours of daily supervised therapy. Practitioners warn sidelining rehab risks recovery and urge enforcement of NHS estates guidance. The Department of Health pledges more community-based rehab centres.

articles.title: What does mistaken release of Hadush Kebatu say about state of prisons in England and Wales?
articles.trailText: The Ethiopian asylum seeker, jailed for sexual assault and due to be deported, was wrongly freed instead
articles.summary: Hadush Kebatu, an Ethiopian asylum seeker convicted of sexually assaulting a teenage girl and sentenced to 12 months in HMP Chelmsford pending deportation, was mistakenly released instead of sent to an immigration centre. After two days on the run—returning confusedly to the prison, then boarding a train to east London—he was recaptured in Finsbury Park. The error highlights understaffing and high caseloads in England and Wales prisons, with 262 unintended releases in 2024–25. Justice Secretary David Lammy plans deportation and a parliamentary statement, amid calls for a national inquiry and new release checks.

articles.title: England and Wales prison checks to be enhanced after inmate released in error
articles.trailText: Justice secretary David Lammy to announce series of measures after Hadush Kebatu was wrongly freed
articles.summary: After Hadush Kebatu—an Ethiopian national convicted of sexually assaulting a 14-year-old—was wrongly freed from HMP Chelmsford, justice secretary David Lammy will roll out enhanced pre-release checks across England and Wales. Kebatu was recaptured in London after a two-day manhunt. The mistake, part of a record 262 erroneous releases in the year to March 2025 (up 128%), has triggered an independent inquiry, suspension of a prison officer and cross-party outrage. Communities secretary Steve Reed blamed past staffing cuts; chief inspector Charlie Taylor awaits details of the new checklists. Kebatu’s asylum claim was rejected and his victim’s father demands immediate deportation.

articles.title: Social landlords in England now forced to fix emergencies within 24 hours
articles.trailText: New legal duties follow case of two-year-old Awaab Ishak, who died after exposure to mould in his home
articles.summary: Awaab’s law, named after two-year-old Awaab Ishak who died from mould exposure, comes into force in England, requiring social landlords to fix emergency hazards within 24 hours, investigate serious damp and mould within 10 working days, make properties safe within 5 working days and report findings within 3 working days. Landlords must offer alternative accommodation if deadlines can’t be met and face court enforcement, compensation and legal costs for non-compliance. Phase 2 next year will cover excess cold, heat, fire and hygiene, with full hazard coverage by 2027, and the renters’ rights bill will extend these duties to private landlords.

articles.title: Over 1,200 health leaders call for swift passage of UK tobacco and vapes bill
articles.trailText: Experts publish letter as peers prepare to scrutinise draft legislation six months after its second Commons reading
articles.summary: Over 1,200 health experts have urged the House of Lords to fast-track the Tobacco and Vapes Bill, which would ban tobacco sales to anyone born on or after 1 Jan 2009 and introduce restrictions on e-cigarette flavours, marketing and packaging. Signatories—doctors, nurses and public health directors—warn that 6 million UK adults still smoke and youth uptake perpetuates deadly addiction. Tobacco firms threaten legal action and have lobbied MPs to weaken provisions. Public opinion is divided: a Forest survey finds 58% support alternative bans while critics highlight industry ties delaying heated tobacco restrictions.

articles.title: NHS leaders warn of longer waiting times if demand for extra £3bn not met
articles.trailText: Key Labour pledge under threat as health service faces costs from redundancies, strikes and rising drug prices
articles.summary: NHS Confederation and NHS Providers have demanded a £3bn emergency fund to cover unbudgeted costs – over £1bn in ICB redundancies, £300m lost to a doctors' strike and up to £2.5bn extra drug costs – warning that without it hospitals will cancel weekend/evening surgery, ration low-clinical-effectiveness treatments and see waiting lists climb above 7.4m. Their demand jams Chancellor Rachel Reeves, facing a £30bn budget gap, after she offered just £650m conditional on DHSC absorbing drug price rises. Leaders warn delays threaten Labour’s pledge to cut waits and derail key reforms amid Whitehall infighting over funding vs reform.

articles.title: Racist incidents against UK nurses surge by 55%
articles.trailText: Royal College of Nursing calls on government to stop using anti-migrant rhetoric, which it says emboldens racist behaviour
articles.summary: RCN analysis shows a 55% surge in racist workplace incidents reported by UK nurses over three years—from around 700 cases in 2022 to over 1,000 this year. Reported abuse includes managers telling staff they “should not have come to the UK,” colleagues saying “you’re not one of us,” patients refusing care from “people like her” and racial slurs. RCN chief Nicola Ranger urges government to cease anti-migrant rhetoric and for employers to enforce anti-racism measures. The health department pledges a PM-ordered review to eliminate racism in the NHS.

articles.title: NHS trialling rapid blood test to help diagnose sepsis and meningitis in children
articles.trailText: The 15-minute test can fast-track detecting whether a patient is suffering from a bacterial or viral infection
articles.summary: The NHS is trialling the 15-minute MeMed BV rapid blood test across paediatric emergency departments at Alder Hey (Liverpool), St Mary’s (London) and Great North (Newcastle) to differentiate bacterial from viral infections, speeding diagnoses of sepsis and meningitis and guiding early antibiotic use. Led by Prof Enitan Carrol and funded by NHS England, the study aims to accelerate clinical decisions, reduce unnecessary antibiotics and improve outcomes. Clinicians report quicker treatment for meningococcal meningitis and sepsis. The trial runs until March and could cut mortality, curb resistance and benefit all ages.

articles.title: The misery of our clocks going back | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Darkened mood | Aston Villa-Maccabi Tel Aviv match | Homeless people | Misheard at a party
articles.summary: A collection of letters covering the psychological impact of clocks going back—particularly for those with seasonal affective disorder who dread darker afternoons—praise for Jonathan Liew’s balanced take on the Aston Villa–Maccabi Tel Aviv match as a measure to avoid violence rather than antisemitism, a challenge to the notion that narrowboat-living children count as homeless, and a humorous mondegreen/eggcorn mix-up at a party where ’heartbreaker’ was misheard as ’harp maker.’

articles.title: Right to buy in reverse: how Brighton is tackling its social housing crisis | Richard Partington
articles.trailText: The council is rolling back Thatcher’s flagship policy by buying stock from private landlords. Other local authorities should take note
articles.summary: Brighton & Hove council is pioneering a “right to buy in reverse” by investing £50m to acquire 200 private flats over two years, replenishing its decimated social housing stock. With near-London prices, rising rough sleeping and 5,000 households on its waiting list, the move aims to reduce homelessness and curb the £3.8m temporary accommodation overspend paid to landlords. The scheme challenges Thatcher’s legacy, offers a model for other councils amid record 1.3m national waiting lists and warns that central funding might sideline high-cost areas like Brighton.

articles.title: Met police urge Epping sex offender spotted in London to hand himself in
articles.trailText: Former asylum seeker Hadush Gerberslasie Kebatu has been missing since being released from prison in error
articles.summary: Met Police are hunting 41-year-old Ethiopian national and convicted sex offender Hadush Gerberslasie Kebatu after he was mistakenly freed from HMP Chelmsford last Friday instead of moved to immigration detention. Jailed for 12 months in September for assaults on a woman and a 14-year-old, Kebatu—still in a grey prison-issue tracksuit and carrying a white avocado-patterned bag—has been spotted across London. Police have deployed specialist teams, appealed for public sightings and urged him to surrender as an investigation into the human error release proceeds. The Prison Service has launched an urgent investigation, while union leaders and the prime minister have condemned the blunder and demanded reforms.

articles.title: Suicides linked to domestic abuse should be investigated as potential homicides, say UK families
articles.trailText: Landmark meeting in Westminster hears from string of relatives who say they have been failed by justice system
articles.summary: Campaigners at a Westminster meeting urged that every suicide following domestic abuse be treated as potential homicide, citing systemic failures by police and the CPS. Project Resist’s “Suicide is Homicide” campaign featured families like Sharon Holland, whose daughter Chloe gathered evidence against her abuser before dying by suicide, and Saskia Lightburn-Ritchie, whose daughter Hannah endured years of coercive abuse. MPs including Kirith Entwistle, Jess Phillips and victims minister Alex Davies-Jones acknowledged legal gaps. The group argues existing laws are underused and calls for thorough investigations, prosecutions and judicial recognition that coercive control can kill. The CPS says it already considers murder or manslaughter where context warrants.

articles.title: Offer cancer patients exercise on NHS, major charity urges
articles.trailText: Maggie’s says embedding activities such as yoga, tai chi and Nordic walking into care could boost chances of survival
articles.summary: Maggie’s, which runs 27 UK cancer support centres offering 13,000 yoga, tai chi, Nordic walking and chair-based sessions annually, is calling on Health Secretary Wes Streeting to embed targeted exercise into NHS cancer care in the delayed national cancer plan. Citing York University research and a landmark study showing physical activity can cut patient mortality by one third, prevent recurrence, improve sleep, mental health and reduce pain, the charity argues routine prehabilitation for Britain’s 386,000 annual diagnoses would save millions and lighten clinician workloads. Cancer Research UK, World Cancer Research Fund and NHS England acknowledge strong evidence and back exploring exercise integration.

articles.title: Scientists demand cancer warnings on bacon and ham sold in UK
articles.trailText: Successive governments criticised for doing ‘virtually nothing’ to reduce risk in the decade since cancer link found
articles.summary: Scientists have urged UK ministers to impose cigarette-style warnings on bacon and ham packaging, citing nitrites—used to cure and preserve meat—as proven bowel carcinogens. A decade after the WHO labelled processed meat as carcinogenic like tobacco and asbestos, experts blame government inaction for 54,000 UK bowel cancer cases and £3 billion in NHS costs. In a letter to Health Secretary Wes Streeting, four IARC scientists and allies call for mandatory warnings on nitrite-packed meat and a phased elimination of nitrites. The WHO found each 50g daily processed meat raises colorectal cancer risk by 18%. The Food Standards Agency disputes conclusive links.

articles.title: Tell us: have you lived in temporary accommodation in the UK with children?
articles.trailText: We want to hear from UK parents with experience in temporary accommodation about the impact on their lives, family and schooling
articles.summary: New figures show 172,000+ children and over 130,000 households in England were in temporary accommodation at the end of June, an 8.2% rise year-on-year. Crisis chief Matt Downie warns children lack space to play, study or call a stable home. The Guardian invites UK parents who have lived with children in temporary housing over the past two years to share details: length of stay, moves away from schools or relatives, effects on education, wellbeing and development. Participants can submit via an online form, subject to the newspaper’s terms and privacy policy.

articles.title: Posh, proud and impossible to ignore: the incredible life of Annabel Goldsmith
articles.trailText: Born in the 1930s, the former Lady Annabel Vane-Tempest-Stewart flourished in a world that celebrated aristocratic rule-breakers. What does her story tell us about how Britain has changed?
articles.summary: Annabel Goldsmith (1933–2025) embodied the public face of postwar British aristocracy, rising from a 15-year-old debutante presented to Queen Elizabeth II, to cofounding Annabel’s nightclub in the 1960s and marrying financier James Goldsmith. Mother to six—Rupert (presumed drowned), Robin, India Jane, Jemima, Zac, Ben—she endured personal tragedies, including a tiger mauling of her son. A confidante to Princess Diana, memoirist and 2004/09 author, she presided over the Democracy Movement in the 2000s, funding anti-EU campaigns. Her life spanned aristocratic visibility’s heyday and its decline into a quieter, meritocratic Britain.

articles.title: Prostate cancer drug that can halve death risk to be offered to thousands in England
articles.trailText: At least 6,000 men a year with hormone-sensitive cancer to get access to darolutamide, which blocks growth with fewer side-effects
articles.summary: NICE has approved darolutamide (Nubeqa, Bayer) for NHS England to treat metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer alongside androgen deprivation therapy. Taken twice daily, the oral agent blocks hormones fueling tumor growth, halving mortality by 46% versus ADT alone, matching existing combo regimens but with fewer side-effects. From 2025, at least 6,000 men annually will gain access. Patient groups praise its gentler profile, especially for older or frailer men, but warn of a regional “postcode lottery” in uptake. NICE and NHS England highlight expanded treatment choice and faster availability to extend life and improve quality for incurable prostate cancer patients.

articles.title: Resident doctors in England to go on strike for five days next month
articles.trailText: Hospital bosses warn 14-19 November stoppage will make it harder to manage winter viruses and tackle waiting lists
articles.summary: Resident doctors in England will undertake a five-day strike from 14 to 19 November— their 13th stoppage since March 2023— after pay and career‐progression talks with Health Secretary Wes Streeting collapsed. The BMA demands a 29% pay rise and faster specialty training access, calling government promises “vague.” Streeting, citing a 28.9% pay uplift over three years, decried the action as “preposterous” and “reckless.” Hospital chiefs warn the dispute will worsen winter virus pressures and delay treatment for 7.4m patients awaiting care.

articles.title: Challenges of council restructure in Kent | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Prof Peter Taylor-Gooby highlights the stark budgetary consequences of government plans to create several new unitary councils
articles.summary: Prof Peter Taylor-Gooby warns that planned restructuring of Kent County Council into three or four unitary authorities risks deepening regional inequality: wealthy West Kent would inherit almost no debt, while East Kent—home to the highest social need—could take on roughly £500m from districts plus £750m from the county, severely limiting its capacity to invest in jobs and services. He urges that social deprivation, investment ability and debt burdens drive the debate to avert a bleak future for East Kent.

articles.title: Asda hires autistic man who was let go by Waitrose after years of volunteering
articles.trailText: Waitrose asked Tom Boyd not to return when he asked for a few hours of paid work after years as unpaid shelf stacker
articles.summary: Tom Boyd, 28, autistic volunteer at Waitrose Cheadle Hulme since 2021, was asked to leave after 600+ unpaid hours when he requested a few paid hours despite no reasonable adjustments. His mother’s Facebook post sparked public outrage, criticism from Mayor Andy Burnham, and calls for a “Bee Neuroinclusive” code. Waitrose later offered paid employment, which Tom declined. Asda responded by hiring him for two flexible five-hour shifts weekly through its supported internship partnership with DFN Project Search, welcoming neurodivergent colleagues.

articles.title: Ministers confirm plans to reduce London’s affordable housing quotas
articles.trailText: Developers will qualify for fast-track planning status if they include 20% affordable housing instead of current 35% target
articles.summary: Housing secretary Steve Reed confirms new rules: developers qualify for fast-track planning if projects include 20% affordable homes (down from 35%), 60% at social rents. Schemes failing to deliver promptly face profit clawback; builders get local tax relief and reduced bike parking requirements. Package, expiring March 2028, aims to revive London’s housebuilding slump amid high interest rates and costs. Critics warn it undermines the homelessness pledge: Shelter data shows the 35% quota drove social home starts from 1,678 to 8,460 in seven years, and Crisis CEO Matt Downie slams the market-led fix amid record homelessness. Mayor Sadiq Khan backs the measures to unlock development.

articles.title: Dozens of Labour MPs warn of chaos for firms over gender recognition advice
articles.trailText: Nearly 50 backbenchers write to business secretary over potential costs and legal ‘minefield’ of upcoming guidance
articles.summary: Nearly 50 Labour backbench MPs have written to Business Secretary Peter Kyle warning that forthcoming EHRC draft guidance on applying the Supreme Court’s definition of “sex” solely as biological risks creating a legal “minefield” and substantial costs for firms. Businesses cite fears of expensive litigation over balancing trans rights with women-only spaces, the expense of retrofitting gender-neutral facilities (one retailer estimated £1.2m for 200 stores), staff unease policing gender, and potential economic and reputational damage from excluding or deterring trans employees and visitors. Ministers will now review the code before laying it before parliament.

articles.title: Care Quality Commission chief quits over maternity inquiry into NHS trust he led
articles.trailText: Julian Hartley says his role at CQC ‘incompatible’ with investigation into Leeds trust he headed for 10 years
articles.summary: Sir Julian Hartley has resigned as chief executive of the Care Quality Commission after an independent Nottingham-style inquiry was ordered into maternity and neonatal failings at Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, which he led for ten years until 2023. Citing an incompatibility between his regulator role and the probe, Hartley apologized to affected families, warning a conflict would undermine confidence. Health secretary Wes Streeting launched the inquiry after parents accused him of overlooking harm. CQC chair Sir Mike Richards called his departure an unselfish but serious loss, appointing Dr Arun Chopra as interim CEO.

articles.title: NHS health checks in England to have questions on menopause for first time
articles.trailText: Experts welcome the addition but urge the health service to improve awareness of checks in the first place
articles.summary: From 2026, NHS health checks for 40-74-year-olds in England will include menopause questions, benefiting 5 million women. The five-yearly check, already screening for heart, kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, dementia and stroke risk, will now flag symptoms like hot flushes, sleep problems and depression. Health Secretary Wes Streeting said the change addresses long-standing gaps, while NICE recommends hormone replacement therapy as first-line treatment to relieve severe symptoms and prevent osteoporosis. Experts including Dr Sue Mann and Prof Ranee Thakar welcomed the update but urged improved access, targeted outreach to deprived and minority communities and clinician menopause training to reduce stigma.

articles.title: The housing crisis needs better solutions than this | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to John Harris’s article about Liverpool’s housing crisis, with many people priced out of buying and having to pay high rents
articles.summary: Letter writers respond to John Harris’s piece on Liverpool’s severe housing crisis, warning that the incoming renters’ rights bill may lack enforceability and alienate small landlords, and urging councils to partner with responsible investors to build genuinely affordable homes. One recalls living in an unheated classroom, fears over green-belt developments, and proposes converting vacant shops and offices into social housing. Another criticizes reduced affordable-housing quotas, foreign investor dominance, and house prices at 7.7× incomes, calling for a major expansion of social and non-profit housing.

articles.title: Samaritans accused of stifling dissent and bullying over branch closure plans
articles.trailText: Claim comes after charity suspends a number of senior volunteers who spoke out publicly against proposals
articles.summary: Samaritans has suspended at least three senior volunteers who publicly criticized its plan to close as many as half of its 201 UK and Ireland branches and move operations into regional call centres. The decision—announced 48 hours before its AGM—has provoked accusations of bullying, with critics warning closures could sever local ties, undermine fundraising and drive away older volunteers unable to travel. Six branch directors demanded a vote of no confidence in chair Keith Leslie. Samaritans defends the overhaul as needed to reduce wait times, noting its helplines receive a call every ten seconds. It says the suspensions follow conduct complaints.

articles.title: NHS staff: have you seen or been affected by violence in hospital?
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear people’s experiences of incidents of violence while working in NHS hospitals
articles.summary: A&E nurses and other NHS staff have experienced a near doubling of violent incidents over six years, according to the Royal College of Nursing. Reports include being punched, spat at and pinned against walls—often by patients or relatives frustrated by long waits. The Guardian is inviting NHS workers to share detailed accounts: what happened, whether incidents were reported internally or to police, and any outcomes, to better understand the extent and impact of hospital violence.

articles.title: Walking just 4,000 daily steps once a week cuts risk of early death in older people, study suggests
articles.trailText: Researchers say the target significantly reduces risk of dying and lowers likelihood of cardiovascular disease
articles.summary: Harvard-led prospective study of 13 547 US women (mean age 72) wearing activity trackers for one week between 2011–15 and followed for over a decade found walking ≥4 000 steps on just 1–2 days a week was linked to a 26% lower all-cause mortality and 27% lower cardiovascular mortality versus none; achieving this on ≥3 days boosted all-cause risk reduction to 40%. Researchers emphasize total step volume, not daily frequency, drives benefits, and flexible “bunched” patterns are viable. Limitations include observational design, single-week monitoring, and female-only sample.

articles.title: UK grooming gang inquiry faces further disruption as candidate for leader withdraws
articles.trailText: Former Lambeth children’s services director Annie Hudson pulls out following intense media coverage
articles.summary: The national grooming gang inquiry ordered by Keir Starmer was further disrupted when shortlisted chair candidate Annie Hudson quit after intense media scrutiny, leaving Jim Gamble as the sole known contender. Three survivors—Fiona Goddard, Ellie Reynolds and “Elizabeth”—resigned from the victims liaison panel, accusing ministers of sidelining survivors, diluting the inquiry’s focus, downplaying racial and religious motives and scripting outcomes. Safeguarding minister Jess Phillips denies cover-up claims and pledges continued engagement with victims.

articles.title: The ultimate meaning of ‘six-sevvuhnn!’ and everything | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: A hitchhiker’s guide to slang | Wassup | Royal formerly known as Prince | Trump tactics | Men practising pilates | Lowering blood pressure
articles.summary: This letters round-up starts with the schoolyard craze of shouting “six-sevvuhnn!”—a playful nod to Douglas Adams’ ‘Answer to the Ultimate Question’ (42). Contributors then recall teenage greetings like “Wassup?”, propose calling Prince Andrew “Andrew, formerly known as Prince,” quip that Trump would cede states that didn’t back him, note men doing pilates, joke that reading the Guardian raises your blood pressure—and invite readers to send in their own letters.

articles.title: Serial rapist who ran Plymouth teeth-whitening salon jailed for 26 years
articles.trailText: Ricky Stubberfield, 31, guilty of 23 sexual offences including attacking some of his own customers
articles.summary: Ricky Stubberfield, 31, co-owner of Essex Smiles teeth-whitening salon in Plymouth, has been jailed for 26 years (plus a six-year extended licence) after admitting 23 sexual offences—including rape, assault by penetration, making indecent images of a child and exposure—against seven victims aged 16–27 between 2013 and 2024. He lured customers with free treatments via Instagram, then attacked them at the salon, a concert venue, in his van and other locations. The court described his conduct as “utterly remorseless predation,” and he must register as a sex offender for life.

articles.title: A day in the life of caring for an overdose survivor
articles.trailText: JB Jarrett lives with devastating brain injuries after overdosing on fentanyl. Despite the uncertainty of his prognosis, his mom, Jessica, is by his side 24/7
articles.summary: Investigative reporter Meridith Kohut follows Jessica Jarrett’s 24/7 caregiving journey for her son JB, 29, who suffered an anoxic brain injury after a 2020 fentanyl overdose. With no official registry for nonfatal overdose survivors, Jessica connects with families via Facebook groups and GoFundMe, manages Hoyer lifts, Baclofen pumps and insurance battles at Houston’s TIRR-Memorial Hermann, and injects joy—pink wheelchairs, tattoo fundraisers—while sleeping beside JB to respond to every need, underscoring the hidden crisis of disabled overdose survivors.

articles.title: Labour urged to rethink scrapping minimum wage youth rates amid ‘Neets’ rise
articles.trailText: Thinktank fears 16- to 24-year-olds not in education, employment or training could be ‘priced out’ of entry-level jobs
articles.summary: The Resolution Foundation warns Labour’s plan to equalise the adult minimum wage by scrapping lower under-21 rates could price 16-24-year-olds out of entry-level jobs amid a surge in Neets. The Neet cohort rose by 195,000 over two years to 940,000, set to top 1m. Labour hiked the 18-20 rate 16.3% to £10 in April (vs £12.21 for 21+). The foundation urges pausing further rises and boosting training, citing rising youth disability, to avoid long-term scarring.

articles.title: Suicide rates among young people in England rose 50% in 10 years, figures show
articles.trailText: Charities accuse government of ‘sliding backwards’ on child mental health after ONS findings
articles.summary: ONS data show suicides among 15- to 25-year-olds in England rose 50% between 2011-12 and 2021-22, from 300 to 440 annual deaths (4,315 over ten years), and 54% per 100,000. Rates spike around summer exams and dip after term starts; females peak in early May (0.53/100,000), males in early July (1.26/100,000). Mind warns half a million under-18s are on mental health waiting lists, a quarter for over two years, accusing government of “sliding backwards.” Charities demand investment in early support hubs, reduced waiting times and national suicide prevention measures.

articles.title: Protective immune cells in breastfeeding women identified as guard against breast cancer, new research finds
articles.trailText: Patients who had more cells had better outcomes, particularly for aggressive types such as triple-negative breast cancer
articles.summary: Research published in Nature finds breastfeeding induces long-lived CD8+ T-cells in breast tissue that persist for over 30 years, bolstering adaptive immunity against breast cancer, especially aggressive triple-negative types. Analysis of noncancerous tissue from 260+ women showed higher T-cell counts in those who’d breastfed. Mouse models confirmed reduced tumor growth dependent on these cells. Clinical data from over 1,000 patients link breastfeeding history to better triple-negative breast cancer outcomes. Insights may guide vaccines or therapies to mimic this protective effect.

articles.title: ‘Six-seven’: what does the latest slang mean (and should parents be worried)?
articles.trailText: It originated in a rap song, then featured in South Park, and is now the bane of schoolteachers in the US and UK as pupils shout it out at random. How did it become such a thing?
articles.summary: Viral meme slang ‘six-seven’, less than a year old, erupted from Philadelphia rapper Skrilla’s 2024 track 'Doot Doot (6 7)' and exploded via NBA star LaMelo Ball clips. Pupils in the US and UK now shout 'six-seven!' — accompanied by upturned palm gestures — to torment teachers. Despite theories about police codes or rating scales, it means only itself: a self-referential youth chant. Some schools ban it, others incorporate it into lessons, but its lifespan may be brief now adults are talking about it.

articles.title: Grooming gang victim quits inquiry panel over ‘condescending language towards survivors’
articles.trailText: Fiona Goddard, who was abused by a gang in Bradford as a child, resigned citing concerns over political interference and treatment of survivors
articles.summary: Fiona Goddard, a childhood grooming gang survivor from Bradford, resigned from Keir Starmer’s national inquiry liaison panel, accusing officials of political interference, conflicts of interest and “condescending and controlling” language toward survivors. She objected to the two shortlisted chairs—ex-police deputy chief constable Jim Gamble and child safeguarding chair Annie Hudson—as representing services she says covered up abuse. Goddard also warned that proposals to broaden the inquiry’s remit risk diluting focus and mistrust reminiscent of IICSA. A 2019 trial convicted nine men; Goddard, who waived her anonymity, said survivors deserve more respect.

articles.title: Low participation in medical trials puts millions of young people at risk
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Data shows gen Z could miss out on new treatments because so few sign up for trials and studies in England
articles.summary: Data analysis by the Guardian shows English 18–24-year-olds account for 8% of the population but only 4.4% of NIHR clinical trial participants (≈7 young people per study), despite nearly half (45%) having long‐term conditions—diabetes, obesity, asthma, epilepsy and mental health disorders. Experts warn this underrepresentation risks future treatments being unsafe or ineffective for Gen Z. Barriers include low awareness, lack of youth‐focused recruitment and design. Calls mount to embed co-design, youth engagement and UK-wide volunteer registries to boost participation and deliver age-appropriate interventions.

articles.title: ‘I wish I had taken part sooner’: how a medical trial transformed a young person’s life
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Gulliver Waite signed up after antidepressants and talking therapies failed to alleviate clinical depression
articles.summary: Gulliver Waite, diagnosed at 19 with clinical depression, endured crippling low mood, anxiety, panic attacks and days sleeping 18 hours. After antidepressants and talking therapies failed, he enrolled in the NIHR-funded PAX-D trial testing pramipexole, a dopamine-mimicking drug. Within days he regained energy, improved sleep quality and lifted mood. Continuing pramipexole post-trial, he has been medication-free for over a year, now works in mental health research and urges young people to join UK volunteer registries to access innovative treatments and support future medical advances.

articles.title: Millions exploited by ‘menopause gold rush’ amid lack of reliable information, say UK experts
articles.trailText: Women’s health academics at UCL call for national education programme to combat misinformation and unregulated advice
articles.summary: UCL women’s health academics warn millions are being exploited by a “menopause gold rush” as companies, celebrities and influencers profit from gaps in reliable information. In a survey of 1,500 UK women, only 22% felt well-informed and 90% backed a national education and support programme—delivered weekly in person or online over two to four weeks—focused on accessible, evidence-based advice, symptom management and myth-busting. Researchers are now developing this government-funded scheme.

articles.title: Don’t cut London’s affordable housing quotas, Labour MPs urge ministers and mayor
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Housing secretary and capital’s mayor face calls from within party for rethink on homebuilding plans
articles.summary: Labour MPs, led by housing select committee chair Florence Eshalomi and Walthamstow MP Stella Creasy, are urging Housing Secretary Steve Reed and London Mayor Sadiq Khan to scrap proposals cutting affordable housing quotas from 35% to 20% in exchange for fast-track planning amid a sharp fall in developments. Official data show just 4,170 homes started in 2024-25, with projections as low as 15,000 by 2027. Campaigners warn reduced quotas will worsen homelessness, while ministers argue drastic measures are needed to tackle London’s housing emergency.

articles.title: Will affordable housing be the casualty as London tackles its building emergency?
articles.trailText: Collapse in construction activity causing alarm but mayor and Whitehall face pushback over ‘extreme solutions’
articles.summary: London’s housebuilding has collapsed: only 40,000 homes under construction—two‐thirds of the normal rate—and just 3,248 private starts in Q1 2025. After raising affordable quotas to 35–50%, social and affordable homes hit 116,000 in 2023, but 21% inflation‐driven cost hikes, higher interest rates, new safety regulations, landfill tax and 36‐week BSR approval delays (holding up 92% of tall‐building plans) have stalled development. With median home prices at 11.5× salaries and 74,720 households in temporary accommodation, ministers are weighing subsidies, tax breaks or cutting quotas amid Labour pushback.

articles.title: Dr Jill Tattersall obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Doctor who co-founded a clinic to provide unmarried women and girls with contraception in Sheffield in the 1960s
articles.summary: Dr Jill Tattersall, who has died aged 95, co-founded Sheffield’s 408 Young People’s Consultation Centre in 1966 to offer contraception and counselling to unmarried and underage girls refused by the NHS until 1974. Born in Epsom in 1929 and evacuated during WWII, she gained entry to Sheffield Medical School on her third application, qualifying in 1956. After early posts in South Shields, she married surveyor Lawrence Tattersall in 1959 and worked for Sheffield Health Authority, specialising in psychosexual medicine. Following her husband’s 1990 retirement, she practised in Cumbria until nearly 70, supported clinics in Zanzibar and the Philippines, and remained active locally. She is survived by three children and six grandchildren.

articles.title: This gift to housebuilders from Labour is shameful | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Aditya Chakrabortty about a leaked memo detailing publicly funded perks offered to developers, including a reduction in affordable properties
articles.summary: Local councillors and planners condemn a leaked memo showing Labour’s proposed cuts to affordable housing obligations—reducing quotas to 20%, suspending section 106 and the community infrastructure levy—and funneling scarce public funds into developer profits. They warn this top-down approach will worsen the housing crisis and undermine roads, schools and GP services, sidelining councils and social landlords. Citing New York, Paris and Vienna’s success with 25–40 percent affordable quotas, they argue stronger requirements do not stall construction. With Persimmon and Berkeley reporting hefty profits, critics say developers can shoulder their fair share to deliver genuinely affordable homes.

articles.title: Sue Barker obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Social worker who took on almost every role across children’s and adults’ services, fostering, adoption and safeguarding
articles.summary: Sue Barker (1946-2025) died aged 79 of pancreatic cancer. Over 50 years she served vulnerable children and adults across England and Wales—as a “house mother” and children’s home manager in Yorkshire, social worker in deprived communities, director of South Tyneside children’s services, regional programme manager for Sure Start and founder of MCRT advising struggling social services. Educated at Leeds Polytechnic (social work) and Northumbria University (MSc), she contributed to Every Child Matters literature. Born in Royston, she married in 1977 and raised two children. Renowned for fierce integrity, non-judgmental compassion and lifelong commitment to safeguarding families.

articles.title: Betfred says gambling tax rise in budget will force it to shut all its UK shops
articles.trailText: Levies thought to be under consideration will kill profits, say bosses, as gambling firms ramp up lobbying efforts
articles.summary: Betfred warns that a proposed increase in gambling duty – potentially raising sports betting rates from 15% to 30–40% and online slots from 20% to 50% – would obliterate its retail arm, forcing closure of all 1,287 UK shops and risking 7,500 jobs. The IPPR projects a £3.2 bn revenue boost; Gordon Brown and Labour back the rise to fund social programmes. William Hill and Entain CEOs foresee similar closures. Betfred posted £500k operating profit on £900m revenues and was fined £3.25m in 2024. HM Treasury declines to confirm tax changes.

articles.title: Woman investigated over husband’s use of assisted dying clinic wanted to argue case in court
articles.trailText: Louise Shackleton says current law is traumatising families and she wanted jury to assess her innocence
articles.summary: Louise Shackleton, 59, spent 10 months under investigation for assisting her husband’s suicide at a Dignitas clinic in Switzerland before the CPS dropped charges. She surrendered to police on return and was interviewed under caution, missing bereavement support and access to her late husband’s farewell letter. Shackleton says she would have preferred a jury trial to prove her innocence and criticizes UK law—where assisting suicide carries up to 14 years—for traumatizing grieving families. With an assisted dying bill now before the House of Lords, she urges legal reform to bring deaths into a regulated, transparent process and spare relatives needless distress.

articles.title: Penalties for unpaid carers in benefits scandal must be halted, says Ed Davey
articles.trailText: Lib Dem leader urges suspension of fines imposed on hundreds of thousands who fell foul of discredited rules
articles.summary: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey urged ministers to suspend fines on thousands of unpaid carers until the government fixes chronic flaws in the carer’s allowance scheme. A Guardian probe found at least 144,000 carers are repaying over £251m—sometimes up to £20,000—because tiny earnings breaches trigger full benefit clawback. He demands publication of Liz Sayce’s independent review and reform of the “cliff-edge” penalty. A Liberal Democrat amendment in the Lords seeks to halt repayments until reforms are enacted. Campaigners say the DWP’s administration failures have created “a national disgrace.”

articles.title: Campaigners urge CPS to reconsider charges against partner of woman who died by suicide
articles.trailText: Inquest into death of Georgia Barter, 32, recorded verdict of unlawful killing, but there was ‘insufficient evidence to pursue case’
articles.summary: Campaigners and domestic abuse charities are urging the Met Police and Crown Prosecution Service to revisit the case of Thomas Bignell, whom a coroner ruled had driven his partner Georgia Barter to suicide in April 2020 after a decade of alleged abuse. Although the assistant coroner recorded unlawful killing, police deemed evidence insufficient for prosecution twice. Advocates demand a fresh CPS referral, legislative reform recognising abuse-induced suicide as manslaughter, and accountability for perpetrators who escape criminal charges despite coroner findings.

articles.title: Labour’s housing hypocrisy: councils serve almost 200 households with no-fault eviction notices
articles.trailText: Exclusive: firms run by five of the party’s councils have used legal loophole in England to serve section 21 notices
articles.summary: A Guardian investigation reveals that since entering government Labour-run councils in England have used arm’s-length housing companies to issue 191 no-fault Section 21 eviction notices, circumventing Keir Starmer’s pledge to ban them. Homes for Lambeth served 63 notices; Homes for Reading 48; Blackpool Housing Company 73; Nottingham City Homes 2; My Housing Gateway 5. Many tenants faced court orders and bailiff removals; some were rehoused in substandard temporary accommodation described as “traumatising.” Councils cite financial and regulatory pressures but promise support amid upcoming legal reforms to outlaw no-fault evictions.

articles.title: Chemical linked to low sperm count, obesity and cancer found in dummies, tests find
articles.trailText: BPA, a synthetic chemical used in production of plastics, found in baby products made by three big European brands
articles.summary: dTest laboratory tests uncovered bisphenol A (BPA) – an endocrine disruptor linked to cancer, obesity and reproductive harm – in pacifiers marketed as "BPA-free" by Philips, Swiss brand Curaprox and French toymaker Sophie la Girafe. Curaprox’s “baby grow with love” soother exceeded the EU migration limit (19 µg/kg vs. 10 µg/kg); Sophie la Girafe and Philips items measured 3 µg/kg and 2 µg/kg respectively. Curaden has recalled and refunded affected Curaprox batches; Vulli and Philips insist their products meet safety thresholds following independent tests. Critics highlight inconsistent EU limits for dummies (10 vs. 40 µg/kg) despite a ban on BPA in baby bottles.

articles.title: Youth clubs are essential parts of the community | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by John Harris on the decimation of youth services
articles.summary: Readers warn that austerity-driven cuts have decimated youth clubs, eroding vital ‘third spaces’ where teens build social skills, autonomy and mental resilience. OnSide CEO Jamie Masraff outlines a hybrid funding model—public funds, philanthropy, business and volunteers—supporting 16 youth zones for 50,000 young people, with six more planned. Contributors highlight girls’ exclusion from male-dominated outdoor facilities, call for safe, moderated environments, and urge governments to invest in professional youth workers as generative community resources rather than cost burdens.

articles.title: Insight is crucial for narcissistic personality disorder | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article about people who have been diagnosed with narcissistic personality disorder
articles.summary: Letters responding to Lucy Knight’s NPD feature stress that patient insight—a cornerstone of psychiatry’s trait spectrum model—is vital: self-aware individuals can mitigate narcissistic tendencies, whereas those at the disorder’s extreme lack insight and exhibit malignant NPD traits (grandiosity, egocentrism, lack of empathy, manipulation, paranoia, aggression). One writer recounts an American relative and Trump supporter whose seven-year inheritance litigation inflicted irreparable financial and emotional harm; another warns that diagnosing personality disorder may exacerbate stigma among mental health professionals and damage therapeutic bonds.

articles.title: Tell us your experiences of private ADHD assessments in England
articles.trailText: If you’ve had a private ADHD assessment in England, we’d like to hear about your experience
articles.summary: A call for patients and professionals in England to share firsthand accounts of private ADHD assessments amid an 18% annual rise in prescriptions since the pandemic. Contributors are asked to detail their diagnostic journey—clinic choice, NHS ‘right to choose’ route, assessment process, costs and wait times—and for clinicians to describe working conditions and sector challenges, to build a clearer picture of private assessment quality and accessibility.

articles.title: ‘Gamechanging’ HIV prevention jab to be approved for England and Wales
articles.trailText: Long-acting injection offers alternative to daily pills taken to protect against the virus
articles.summary: Nice has recommended cabotegravir (CAB-LA), a bi-monthly long-acting HIV prevention injection, for adults and young people in England and Wales unable to take daily oral PrEP. Nice’s medicines evaluation director Helen Knight said it fills a gap for about 1,000 people with contraindications to pills.
